title: Restrict any user from logging into his account.

activities.message:
But what are the security implications of this, other than being an annoyance to yourself? Because you are only able to capture requests of your own account. So if you would script something that logs yourself in automatically, you would only annoy yourself.

Your prerequisite seems highly unobtainable. If you would be able to gain access to another user's account through hacking our platform, that report would be much more valuable to us.
activities.markdown_message:
But what are the security implications of this, other than being an annoyance to yourself? Because you are only able to capture requests of your own account. So if you would script something that logs yourself in automatically, you would only annoy yourself.

Your prerequisite seems highly unobtainable. If you would be able to gain access to another user's account through hacking our platform, that report would be much more valuable to us.

activities.message:
I saw hackerone accepted many reports related to user's session.Most of them were regarding,session not being destroyed after a password change,email change etc.So,what was the point on those case?The same way attacker would get hold on to victims session on those report,the same way attacker can obtain victim's old session.And once he got it ,he can refrain the victim user from logging into his own account.
The main issue is same here,old session is not completely destroyed.It can still be used to do some action.As I explained,it can be used to log out that particular user.
**Referring to other report can never be a very good principle,I know it**.But you left me with no other option here.

Ref:
1. https://hackerone.com/reports/17383
2. https://hackerone.com/reports/15785
3. https://hackerone.com/reports/288
4. https://hackerone.com/reports/284
In all the above report,reporter needed to have access to one old session.So the pre-requisition  doesnt seem so strange.
I hope I was able to clarify the matter.

Thanks

activities.message:
This just doesn't make sense to me. I still think your prerequisite is very hard to obtain. If this were a report where you'd explain how to obtain such a session by exploiting a vulnerability I wouldn't close this as Not Applicable, but I'm not seeing any security vulnerability. Destroying the session after logging out seems like a very good security measure to me. The last thing I would do as a hacker is annoy someone by destroying the victim's session – there are much worse thing someone could do

I'm afraid I have to close this as N/A. Keep hacking!
activities.markdown_message:

Destroying the session after logging out seems like a very good security measure to me. The last thing I would do as a hacker is annoy someone by destroying the victim's session – there are much worse thing someone could do

I'm afraid I have to close this as N/A. Keep hacking!

activities.message: @siddiki as you probably now by now we reopened this bug. Although it's very hard to misuse this and needs a prerequisite that an attacker is unlikely to obtain (if so, you probably could do more interesting stuff than logging out the user), we still think this is worth fixing.
activities.markdown_message: @siddiki as you probably now by now we reopened this bug. Although it's very hard to misuse this and needs a prerequisite that an attacker is unlikely to obtain (if so, you probably could do more interesting stuff than logging out the user), we still think this is worth fixing.

activities.message:
Thank you for reopening this.With an old destroyed session,what an attacker could do other than refraining that target user from login into his account,I actually dont know.I tried many other request,but nothing goes well with that old session.Probably you are missing one point.Everytime you are saying that I just can logout the remote user.But this is not.When 5-6 thread per second will run with the old session,it will be impossible for that remote user to login into his account.
What solution do you have for that user,who can not login into his account with valid password?

What solution do you have for that user,who can not login into his account with valid password?

activities.message: @siddiki we're still working on this. It might take a while, sorry.
activities.markdown_message: @siddiki we're still working on this. It might take a while, sorry.

activities.message:
I understand that the severity of this issue doesn't warrant a priority fix,but if you can provide me an ETA that will be much appreciated.

Thanks

activities.message: Thanks for your patience! We're still working on a fix, but as you know it's lower priority so we don't have a defined ETA. We'll keep you posted with our progress.

activities.message: As this bug is not a real security vulnerability, and an annoyance at most, we've decided to mark this bug as ineligible for a bounty. Thanks again for taking the time to report this bug!
activities.markdown_message: As this bug is not a real security vulnerability, and an annoyance at most, we've decided to mark this bug as ineligible for a bounty. Thanks again for taking the time to report this bug!

vulnerability_information_html:
Hackerone's destroys user sessions automatically after signing out,changing password etc.So Old sessions are seems to be worthless for any attacker.But I found something,by exploiting this you can restrict any hackerone user to logging into his account.

Pre-Requisition
I just need one of his old sessions.

steps to reproduce

  1. Login to hackerone.
  2. Capture any request.
  3. Send it to burp intruder.
  4. Logout from hackerone.
  5. Now start intruding that captured request,which is carrying the old destroyed session.
  6. Try log in from other device.
  7. Every time burp intruder sends a request,the present logged in account will be logged out automatically. So if you keep continue intruding,that user will never be able to login to his own ID.
vulnerability_information:
Hackerone's destroys user sessions automatically after signing out,changing password etc.So Old sessions are seems to be worthless for any attacker.But I found something,by exploiting this you can restrict any hackerone user to logging into his account.

**Pre-Requisition**
I just need one of his old sessions.

**steps to reproduce**
1. Login to hackerone.
2. Capture any request.
3. Send it to burp intruder.
4. Logout from hackerone.
5. Now start intruding that captured request,which is carrying the old destroyed session.
6. Try log in from other device.
7. Every time burp intruder sends a request,the present logged in account will be logged out automatically.
So if you keep continue intruding,that user will never be able to login to his own ID.

profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.
profile.name: HackerOne
